newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli shares end five-session new year's rise.
newsitem.headline: Israeli shares end five-session new year's rise.

text.p: Israeli shares ended a new year's winning streak, closing lower in what traders described as a technical correction to an 8.9 percent rise over five sessions.

The Tel Aviv stock exchange's benchmark Mishtanim index of the top 100 shares fell 0.97 percent, or 2.24 points, to 227.60 on all-share turnover of 133 million shekels against 172 million shekels on Wednesday.
The Maof 25 blue chip index closed 1.10 percent lower at 235.59.

"The market looks healthy. After a very sharp rise the long awaited correction finally came. During the last three months the market rocketed and now it's time to take profits," said Michael Weiss at Evergreen Capital Markets who added that the immediate outlook was unclear.
"The correction is very good for the market. If nothing dramatic happens on Wall Street the market will continue to rise soon," said Danni Scharia at Capital Securities.

"Despite today's decline the market was mixed and activity continued to be relatively high. The market is also affected by the fact that mutual funds specialising in small-capitalisation stocks returned to buying," Scharia added.
The most active share was Israel Chemicals, which gained 0.5 percent to 316 agorot on turnover of 6.2 million shekels.
The second active share was Africa Israel Investments, which plunged 29 percent to 201,159 agorot on volume of 6.1 million shekels.

Africa was traded today for the first time without its insurance business. On Sunday, shareholders will receive shares in Leumi Insurance Holdings. The distribution is part of a multi-faceted transaction under which Italian insurer Generali is buying control of Leumi Insurance.
Africa's 01 issue dropped 23 percent to 23,357 agorot.
Koor Industries, fell 1.75 percent to 19,951 agorot on turnover of 5.0 million shekels.
